section.title: Mailbox Creation Distribution
section.para: A default backend can be configured in imapd.conf with the defaultserver setting on a frontend, and a default partition can be configured with defaultpartition on a backend.
Alternatively, backend or partition selection is controlled with serverlist_select_mode on the frontend and partition_select_mode on the backend.

section.title: Selection Modes
section.para: Selection modes configurable on frontend and backend do share the same principles. In each case, a list of available items are considered: those are the backends when creating the mailbox through a frontend, and the partitions when being on the backend. Depending on the configured selection mode, each item has an associated (disk) capacity and free space which will be used to select the most fitting one.

note.title: Unified mupdate
note.para: Please remember that when using a unified mupdate configuration, a server is both a frontend and a backend: you can create and access local or remote mailboxes. Since configuration settings are distinct for each role the server can take, you can apply different selection modes for each role.

listitem.para: Choice is (pseudo-)random. Each item has the same probability of being selected.
The item which has the most free space (counted in KiB units) is selected. That is the default selection mode.

example.title: Example of freespace-most Selection
example.para: Suppose that the available items are:

listitem.para: item1 with 1000GiB of capacity, 400GiB being free (40% free space)
item2 with 1000GiB of capacity, 600GiB being free (60% free space)
item3 with 100GiB of capacity, 30GiB being free (30% free space)
item4 with 100GiB of capacity, 70GiB being free (70% free space)

example.para: In that case item2 will be selected as most fitting, since 600GiB of free space is the biggest of all.

listitem.para: The item which has the most percentage of free space is selected.

example.title: Example of freespace-percent-most Selection
example.para: In the same conditions than item4 would be selected as most fitting, since 70% of free space is the biggest of all.

listitem.para: For each item, the percentage of free space is its weight. Then a weighted choice is performed to select one of those items.
As such, the more free space the item has, the more chances it has to be selected.

note.title: Usage convergence
note.para: Using the freespace-percent-weighted mode, items percentage usages will converge towards 100%. So if they have different usages, those differences will stay and only really diminish upon reaching 100% of usage.
You may also observe growing differences between items usages when they do not have the same total disk space.

listitem.para: As for freespace-percent-weighted, a weight is associated to each item. It is computed as follows: (percentage of freespace of item) - (lowest percentage of freespace of all items) + 0.5
Then a weighted choice is performed to select one of those items.
As such, considering the usage percentages, the more the item is lagging behind the most used one (which has the lowest percentage of free space), the more chances it has to be selected.

note.title: Computed weight
note.para: The added 0.5 in items weight is so that selection gets smoother when all items usage percentages get close to each other.

note.para: Using the freespace-percent-weighted-delta mode, items percentage usages will converge towards the most used one. And then items usage will grow equally.

section.title: What happens when two items are equal as most fitting ?
section.para: The freespace-most and freespace-percent-most modes do select the item with the most free space or percent of free space. It may happen that two or more items do have the same value. If this value appears as most fitting, only one item will be selected, but you may not know in advance which one will be. In particular, it may not be the first one that appears listed in your configuration.
Also note that after the mailbox is created on the selected item, it will have less free space and thus shall not be seen as most fitting next time.

section.title: What happens when two items are actually the same ?
section.para: Each item has an associated id:

listitem.para: its device id for a partition

section.para: If two or more items share the same id when using the freespace-most or freespace-percent-most mode, only one of those items will actually be checked, as if the others were not configured. As for , you may not know in advance which one will be.

section.title: Items Exclusion
section.para: When using a selection mode other than random, items can be automatically excluded if their usage percentage is beyond a configured integer setting:

note.title: Soft usage limit
note.para: If all items are beyond the configured value, this feature is automatically deactivated. An item is thus selected as if the setting was not set.

important.title: Exclusion is not absolute
important.para: Items are only excluded when creating a new user mailbox according to the configured selection mode.
If you explicitly specify an excluded item, the mailbox will be created on that item.
Mailboxes previously created there are of course still accessible, and subfolders are by default still created at the same place than the parent folder.

section.title: Items Usage Data Reset
section.para: By default items usage data are retrieved only once upon service initialization (that is when an imapd instance is created). This only concerns selection modes other than random.

If you tend to use the same service instance for a long lapse of time and perform a large amount of mailboxes creation, usage data will soon be out-of-date. For the cases where it is useful to refresh those data, you can configure the number of creation requests after which data are resetted:

section.title: Application
section.para: What each item (disk) capacity and free space represents depends on the situation.

section.title: On backend
section.remark: There should be a chapter giving details on how partitions (for data and metadata) are configured. Maybe adding a link to there would be useful ?
section.para: On the backend a partition is represented by its disk capacity and free space. Each example listed in can be interpreted in a straightforward way by replacing references to item by partition.

section.title: Partitions Exclusion
section.para: For details on exclusion based on disk usage, see .

example.title: Example of partition exclusion using partition_select_soft_usage_limit
example.para: In the same conditions than , setting partition_select_soft_usage_limit to 50 would exclude partitions item1 and item3 since their disk usage is respectively 60% and 70%.
But setting the option to 20 would have no effect, since all partitions have a usage which is beyond 20%.

section.para: Aside from automatic exclusion based on disk usage, partitions listed in the partition_select_exclude setting are permanently excluded from being selected.

note.para: Listed partitions names are separated by space, tabulation or comma. Only configured partition names (and not paths) are expected.

example.title: Example of permanent partition exclusion
example.para:
With the following configuration in imapd.conf, parta and partb would be permanently excluded from being selected:
partition-part1: /path/to/partition1 partition-part2: /path/to/partition2 partition-part3: /path/to/partition3 partition-part4: /path/to/partition4 partition-parta: /path/to/partitiona partition-partb: /path/to/partitionb
partition_select_exclude: parta partb

section.title: On frontend
section.remark: There should be a chapter giving details on how backends are configured (next to the one about backend partitions). Maybe adding a link to there would be useful ?
section.para: On the frontend a backend is represented by its available partition with the most percentage of free space, except for the freespace-most mode where it is the sum of all its available partitions. Of course this does not apply to the random mode.

example.title: Example of backend representation on frontend
example.para: Suppose that a backend has a 2000GiB capacity, 900GiB being free (45% free space), composed of 2 partitions

listitem.para: part1 which has a 1000GiB capacity, 200GiB being free (20% free space)
part2 which has a 1000GiB capacity, 700GiB being free (70% free space)

example.para: That backend would be represented by:

listitem.para: its partition part2 for the freespace-percent-most, freespace-percent-weighted and freespace-percent-weighted-delta modes, since that partition has the most percentage of free space: that is a 1000GiB capacity, 700GiB being free (70% free space)
the sum of all its available partitions for the freespace-most mode: that is a 2000GiB capacity, 900GiB being free (45% free space)

section.para: Keeping that in mind, you can refer to examples listed in to determine how most fitting backends are selected.
